abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Student Loan Reform
            Project is considered unsatisfactory with unlikely
            sustainability, modest development impact, and
            unsatisfactory performance by both the Bank and the
            Borrower. The project did achieve many of its targets, but
            failed to meet its overall development objectives. Poor
            quality at entry, including weak project rationale, poor
            potential impact assessment, no counterfactual
            consideration, decisions made due to poor or contradictory
            data, not addressing incongruent policies, unrealistic risk
            assessment, poor matching of resources to tasks, as well as
            poor resource allocation among components, led to the
            unsatisfactory rating. Lessons learned include: carefully
            weigh rationale for undertaking project against other
            alternatives; draw on previous country and sector experience
            as well as similar projects; propose realistic objectives
            and components; substantiate project objectives by baseline
            economic data; use long-term impact performance indicators;
            contemplate various scenarios in project funding; improve
            financial management and reporting prior to lending for
            student loan projects; include a financial specialist;
            carefully evaluate and monitor project risks; be flexible to
            adjustments in components and legal agreements; scrutinize
            institutional structure to maximize performance; and that
            lack of continuity in management leads to a loss of
            institutional memory and in turn affects implementation,
            outputs, and outcomes.
